For more on the acute shortage of nurse educators, we turn back to Mary Jane Williams, one of the voices you just heard.

Doctor Williams, I was struck by that figure that the United States needs to produce 90 percent more nursing graduates in the coming years in order to meet our demand for nurses.
What will happen to health care in this country if that goal is not met?
When I talked to my colleagues, many of them tell me that they're hiring nurses who are not educated at the RN level because they can't find them.
So they're hiring people who are at the license practical nurse level or they're using a multi-skilled worker who might not even be a licensed practitioner.
So I think we are facing eminent danger in being able to provide safe patient care when you see nurses as the key to the health care delivery system.
What do you see as the root of the shortage of nursing teachers.
Is it merely a question of the nurses who have that kind of education that they can make more money actually nursing than they can - teaching?
There are multiple issues related to the academic role.
Many people who select the academic role are disillusioned with it because of the demands.
The other thing is the students have changed tremendously.
A lot of the people that are coming into nursing now are coming in as a second career or are changing their careers because they see nursing as a place where employment will be continuous.
The average student entering a program is no longer 18 years old.
The mean age is much closer to 30.
The adult comes in.
They come to class and then they have to go home.
They have to find time to study.
They have to find time to do the things that their life requires them to do.

I think that what we have to do is move people through the educational system for nursing earlier and faster.
It has been traditional to nursing to have nurses practice for a while.
I don't believe that that's essential.

A prominent journalist in Russia was also killed today.
The body of Anna Politkovskaya was found with several gunshot wounds by the elevator of her Moscow apartment building.
Nina Ognianova followed her career for the Committee to Protect Journalists.
Politkovskaya was an incredible investigative professional.
She was a special correspondent for the independent Moscow newspaper, Novaya Gazeta.
And she was particularly known for her investigative reports on human rights abuses by the Russian military in Chechnya.
This is a topic that is very sensitive for the Kremlin and President Putin.
And in the seven years covering the second Chechen war, her reporting on human rights abuses committed by the Russian military there repeatedly drew the wrath of Russian authorities.
Politkovskaya had written a highly critical book about President Putin, never published in Russia.
She'd been threatened in the past, jailed, and forced at one point into exile.
After she wrote about a Chechen man who had disappeared, Politkovskaya started receiving e-mail death threats from a Russian Special Forces officer who had interrogated the missing man.
And when Politkovskaya tried to report on the terrorist siege of a school in southern Russia, she was apparently poisoned.
She boarded a plane en route to Beslan and was served tea onboard, after which she fell gravely ill.
The toxin that went into her body was never identified because the medical personnel who admitted her into the hospital and gave her treatment was instructed to destroy the results of the expertise.
Moscow prosecutors have opened a murder investigation.
Former Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev called the killing a blow to the entire democratic independent press, a grave crime against the country, against all of us.
The New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists has documented a dozen contract style killings of journalists in Russia since the year 2000.
Anna Politkovskaya was 48 years old.
She had two children.
